summary: This document is a chain of emails from June 2020 between FBI personnel and AUSAs discussing the processing and transfer of digital evidence seized from Jeffrey Epstein's properties in New York and the US Virgin Islands. The emails focus on logistical challenges, data formatting issues, and the need to coordinate for a conference call regarding the Epstein and Nygard cases.

persons.name: Rozier
persons.context: Mentioned as part of the U.S. Attorney's Office case team who can join a conference call to discuss the evidence processing issues.

connections.description: Both are involved in the Epstein case, with M as FBI SSA and Rozier as AUSA, needing to coordinate on evidence processing and legal strategy.

events.title: Request for Epstein-Nygard Conference Call
events.description: FBI SSA M requests a conference call for the next day to discuss Epstein and Nygard cases, indicating coordination between investigations.

events.title: Epstein Property Searches
events.description: Reference to searches conducted in July (and September) at Epstein's properties, from which digital evidence was seized and is being processed.

events.title: Evidence Processing Delays
events.description: Discussions about significant delays in processing terabytes of digital evidence from multiple devices due to staffing issues and the complexity of the data.

keyFacts: The FBI and SDNY were processing a massive amount of digital evidence (terabytes) seized from Jeffrey Epstein's New York and US Virgin Islands properties in July and September searches.

There were significant logistical and technical challenges in transferring and reviewing the evidence, including formatting issues with Relativity, matching documents to specific devices, and staffing shortages.
The case was described as 'top-driven on both sides (FBI and SDNY) due to the incredible amount of media attention it has received,' indicating high-level pressure.
A conference call was requested to discuss both the Epstein case and the Nygard case, suggesting investigative coordination or overlap.
The emails reveal internal friction and miscommunication between the FBI's Computer Analysis Response Team (CART) and the U.S. Attorney's Office over evidence handling procedures.
